thread.title: Newcastle boss Rafael Benitez questioning his future after they make ZERO winter window signings
thread.title_full: Newcastle boss Rafael Benitez questioning his future after they make ZERO winter window signings

author: Simon Bird
title: Newcastle boss Rafael Benitez questioning his future after they make ZERO winter window signings
text:
Newcastle boss Rafael Benitez questioning his future after they make ZERO winter window signings Showdown talks loom as the Spaniard feels the Championship promotion chasers have moved the goalposts Share Benitez won't quit now but has his doubts about the Newcastle 'project' (Photo: Getty) Share   Thank you for subscribing!   
Rafa Benitez's future as Newcastle manager has been thrown into doubt by the club’s disastrous January transfer window. 
Boss Benitez is furious the Magpies failed to bring in ANY of his targets, and feels that the terms under which he agreed to take the job on last year have changed. 
The Spaniard took charge of transfers and lined up a series of potential new recruits, including a return for Andros Townsend, but the Toon hierarchy could not get any deals done before Tuesday night's deadline. 
That has left the United boss fearing he is no longer in control of the key levers of power at St James’ Park. Townsend shone for Benitez in last season's doomed battle against the drop... (Photo: Reuters) ...and the Spaniard wanted him back, but he has stayed at Crystal Palace (Photo: PA) 
And he is concerned that, even if he is still in control, there is little point if the club won’t pay the money for players he believed were needed to bolster their bid for an instant return to the top flight after last season's relegation. 
Benitez will hold showdown talks over his future in the summer. 
He will demand strong guarantees that he can rebuild the club into one that can challenge for the top half of the Premier League – if they do get promoted in May – without interference from other club employees. 
Chief scout Graham Carr still wields influence, and sat next to owner Mike Ashley at the FA Cup third round tie at Birmingham in early January. Benitez is fretting over whether Carr has acted as a brake on his transfer wish list. 
He was baffled why Newcastle didn’t land Townsend , who he believed would return to Tyneside for £13m — the size of the deal that took him from Tyneside to Crystal Palace in the summer. The Magpies do look like going up, but what will Ashley do if/when they get there? (Photo: MirrorPix) 
When the transfer window slammed shut on Tuesday, Benitez observed: “I said we were ready to sign players at the beginning of January but after we didn’t do anything.” 
The Spaniard has been left wondering why Ashley, who he has had a relatively productive relationship with, swayed from solid promises made in the summer about transfer strategy. 
Have the club clawed back some power, or are they simply keeping their powder dry for a splurge ahead of an assault on the top flight? 
The 56-year-old former Valencia, Liverpool, Inter Milan, Chelsea, Napoli and Real Madrid boss has dealt with difficult owners in the past, and knows internal club politics comes with the job. 
He is happy to be responsible, and accountable, for all signings made, and doesn’t want his ambitious plans to be blocked. Newcastle are on course to go back up — but Benitez wants to build a top-flight force (Photo: PA) 
Benitez is proud of his transfer record so far at Newcastle. He believes he has achieved a 70 per cent hit rate and that represents an excellent return. 
Dwight Gayle, Matt Ritchie and Isaac Hayden have been big hits and might fetch double their summer fees. Ciaran Clark has done well. Others were bought to do a job in the Championship and provide cover, and have not lost value. 
The two mistakes are probably keeper Matz Sels and full-back Jesus Gamez, but they are hardly disasters of Remy Cabella or Florian Thauvin standard. 
Whatever the politics, the club has taken a major gamble in recruiting no new players, as rivals have plugged gaps in their teams and became stronger. Cabella arrived in an £8m deal — he managed ONE goal for Newcastle (Photo: Getty) 
Benitez is likely to have job offers elsewhere come June, and West Ham have been interested in the recent past. He has a strong loyalty to the Geordie fans who have invested faith in his regime, but that could be tested. 
There is no chance of him quitting now, and he refused to make his full feelings about the situation known in public. 
Despite his misgivings, he has spoken of creating a positive atmosphere to help his players win promotion and “become heroes” on Tyneside. 
He said: “We have to stick together. Win promotion and they will be heroes, they will be famous. 
“We have to bring the best from the players we have and keep winning games. Obviously we can’t change anything. We have to lead the players and make sure they are ready for the next match.” Like us on Facebook
